awd_titl_txt: Food Web Structure and Importance of Macroalgal Carbon      to Coastal Communities of the Antarctic Peninsula Based     on Stable Carbon & Nitrogen Isotope Signatures
awd_abstract_narration: The importance of marine macroalgae in coastal food webs of the                 Antarctic Peninsula is not well known.  Dr. Kenneth Dunton, using               marine flora and fauna collected from several sites on the                      Antarctic Peninsula, proposes to determine the contribution of                  macroalgal carbon to the rich benthic communities by using stable               carbon and nitrogen isotopic signatures.  The density of coastal                macroalgae is extremely high, the productivity of which probably                matches or exceeds that of the local phytoplankton.  The                        hypothesis to be tested is that macroalgae serve as an important                dietary carbon source of many benthic and epibenthic fauna, as                  recently demonstrated for kelps in low latitudes.  The stable                   isotopic analysis of the collected fauna and flora will provide                 an unique opportunity to evaluate the contribution of macroalgal                carbon in high latitude food webs, as well as trophic relations                 and feeding strategies of marine fauna on the Antarctic                         Peninsula.
